Introduction

This policy is to ensure that the Occupational Health Department and Wellbeing service (OH&WBS) provides a comprehensive service available to all employees, ensuring all employees experience a working environment for which they are physically and mentally suited and which promotes and protects not only the individual workers health; but also the general wellbeing of the patients, visitors and contractors.
The aim of the policy is to:
Promote and maintain the physical, mental and social wellbeing of all employees.
Ensure all staff have access to an OH service and are aware of the clinical services available to support them in maintaining optimum health.

Ensure that the physical and mental demands imposed on employees at work by their respective jobs are properly matched with their individual anatomical, physiological and psychological capabilities, needs and limitations.
Contribute to increasing the effectiveness of the Trust by enhancing staff performance and morale through reducing risks at work that may lead to ill- health, staff absences and accidents.
Support and advise accordingly both the employer and employee in any issues pertinent to Occupational Health.
Advise both staff and management on the protection of employees against any physical or environmental hazard, which may arise from their work.
Ensure compliance to any legislation or recommendations pertaining to OH at work i.e. health surveillance.
Contribute to reducing sickness absence by providing a managed service with effective operating systems
Scope
This document is applicable to all employees who are directly employed by the Trust, whether full-time or part-time, permanent or temporary including those employed by the Trust via the Staff Bank
This policy is also applicable to all employees within external organisations for whom the Occupational Health and Wellbeing Service provides services under Service Level Agreement.
Definitions

table_items.text: Health Care Worker - Any employee that may have contact with patients and/or blood or body fluids, therefore this would include pathology, therapists, security, portering staff and domestic service assistants

Exposure Prone Procedure - EPPs are those invasive procedures where there is a risk that injury to the worker may result in exposure of the patients open tissues to the blood of the worker. These include procedures where the workers gloved hands may be in contact with sharp instruments, needle tips or sharp tissues (e.g. spicules of bone or teeth) inside a patient's body, cavity or confined anatomical space where the hands or fingertips may not be completely visible at all times.
Pre-Placement Health Questionnaire. The questionnaire applicants complete prior to their confirmed job offer. It assess fitness for the role

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive

The ultimate responsibility for Health and Safety lies with the Chief Executive who must ensure that all parts of the organisation have a suitable policy and that its implementation is monitored regularly to ensure its effectiveness.
Associate Director of Occupational Health & Wellbeing
Responsible for;
Ensuring implementation of this policy
Ensuring provision of a comprehensive and effective occupational health service
Assisting operational managers to achieve their responsibilities under this policy
Ensuring the department complies with local and national guidelines with reference to health and safety, infection prevention and immunisations
Ensuring the occupational health department works within relevant statutory guidance
Identifying income generation opportunities with regard to provision of Occupational Health Services to outside organisations
Occupational Health Physician
Responsible for:
Providing clinical leadership to the occupational health department
Supporting the occupational health manager to fulfil their role
Ensuring clinical occupational health practice is compliant with all relevant and applicable practice
Occupational Health Staff
Responsible for:
Stressing the importance of comprehensive occupational health management being integrated into mainstream management responsibilities

Highlighting the potential of the occupational health service to help employers and managers improve effectiveness and reduce costs through the reduction of sickness absence. They also aim to improve the quality of patient care and other Trust services through improved staff morale
Reducing ill-health in the workforce caused or exacerbated by work and consequently improve patient care and health

Enabling employees to come back to work earlier than anticipated through phased return programmes, restriction of duties, referral to specialists etc. with the collaboration of the Employee Relations Team and Line Managers
Complying with the Occupational Health Policy. Failure to do so will be dealt
with as an employment issue
Trust Managers
Responsible for:
Ensuring that occupational health related policies are available to all staff within the Trust

Collaborating with the central governance team and health and safety committee to assess and manage the risks to health caused by the working environment, according to the Health and Safety legislation

Collaborating with other equally accountable parties ensure a safe and healthy working environment for employees, contractors, members of the public and visitor with the aid of risk management and recent COSHH assessments, determine the risk to health from microbiological and chemical hazards.
Aiming to prevent and/or control exposure. Inform employees of the risk, monitor exposure where required and instigate health surveillance and/or prophylactic measures where required
Reporting injuries, diseases and dangerous occurrences according to regulations locally, nationally, and legally
Ensuring all employees have access to a confidential occupational health service
Ensuring all successful candidates for employment complete a health questionnaire which is referred to the occupational health department for screening
Ensuring staff are referred to OH&WBS in line with Sickness Policy. Where relevant managers can contact OH&WBS or the Employee Relations Team for advice on who and when to refer employees
Ensuring employees are referred when work may be a contributing factor to the individual's ill-health or for work performance related issues which may be contributed by ill-health
Employees
Responsible for:
Being aware of this policy and the functions of the OH&WBS
Attending appointments with the OH when requested to do so by their line manager
Informing the OH&WBS of any changes in their health which may affect their ability to work
Access to the service
The OH&WBS service is situated on three hospital sites: Basildon:H Block
Southend: 22 Cardigan Avenue
Broomfield : West Wing – C453
The opening hours are from 08:00-16:30, Monday to Friday (excluding bank
holidays). There is advice available on-line 24/7.
Individuals who require urgent assessment following a high-risk sharp, needle stick or body fluid exposure outside of these hours are advised to contact the Emergency Department.

OH&WBS operates an appointments system although it may be possible to see individuals who do not have an appointment in the cases of high risk needle stick or body fluid exposure or distressed staff as part of the Escalation process who cannot access Wellbeing Allies or other support services.
Contact number for Occupational Health is Basildon 01268 524 900 – Ext 3591 (internally 773 3591).
Confidentiality and storage

No details of an employee's medical condition will be communicated to a third party without the specific written consent of the individual employee, unless in the interest of public health, under this circumstance permission would be sought from the Caldicott Guardian.

Patient information is stored electronically on the OH database (Cohort) which is password protected. Only occupational health clinical and administrative staff have access to this system. Information in paper format is stored in locked cabinets within a locked room in the occupational health department. Access to this area is restricted to occupational health staff only. Some historic paper notes are stored off site in a secure, confidential system.
Copies of occupational health notes are only released to the employee following receipt of a written request. Contact occupational health by email – mse.occhealth@nhs.net
All occupational health records are kept in accordance to the General Data Protection Regulations GDPR.
Functions of the service
Health screening
The purpose of the work health assessment is to assess the health of the employee in relation to the physical and psychological demands of the proposed employment.
The assessment also aims to ensure as far as reasonably practicable; that the prospective employee does not represent a risk to others.

The pre-placement health screening questionnaires of all successful candidates to whom job offers have been made are forwarded to the occupational health department are submitted on-line via the Cohort system to maintain confidentiality.
Questionnaires and health clearances are also required to be updated by existing employees of the Trust transferring between posts within the Trust.

If a young person aged  to 18 years is employed or engaged in any capacity; then a young person's risk assessment must be completed and a copy sent to occupational health. If any hazards are identified then these must be discussed with the parents or guardian of that young person prior to commencing employment.
The process

In accordance with the Equality Act 2010 employers are not permitted to ask the applicant questions relating to their health until after an offer of employment (on a conditional or unconditional basis) has been made.
The Recruitment department will send the Pre-Placement Health questionnaire (PPQ) (Appendix 1) on-line link to the successful candidates following their interview
The completed questionnaire will then be completed on-line and notification sent to the occupational health department for it to be processed within 2 working days of receipt.

The questionnaire will be triaged by the Occupational Health Nurse Advisor who will advise on fitness for role or whether there is a delay in connection of the individual's fitness as further information is required.
The Recruitment department will then be notified of the decision which will be one of the following:

Fit for post without restriction: Where the information in the health questionnaire satisfies the criteria in relation to the proposed employment. No appointment at the Occupational Health Department will be necessary.
Clearance deferred awaiting further information: The employee will be informed fully about the information required to satisfactorily complete clearance.
An interim clearance with applicable restrictions or adjustments may be issued.

Deferment may be due to requiring information from GPs and/or previous occupational health departments, confirmation of vaccination status or completion of serological investigations pertinent to their proposed employment.
There may be Circumstances where individuals must attend an occupational health assessment/telephone assessment
Attendance/telephone assessment will be required at the discretion of the Occupational Health Adviser.
The Occupational Health Adviser / Physician is not involved in the selection process for employment.
Occupational health clearance relates to fitness for role and any adjustments needed to befit for role.
Sickness absence management and ill health performance
services
Referral procedure

The self-referral system is not routinely available and staff are directed to their line manager for a management referral to be completed. We have a duty of care to our employees and it is important that the local manager is aware of any health concerns to ensure that appropriate considerations are made.

Employees can access all the information available for counselling services, self- referral to MSK physiotherapy treatment and all wellbeing services via the intranet by searching on Workspace - Occupational Health and Wellbeing department
Any request for a self-referral should be discussed by contacting the OH&WB service via telephone or email and discussing the request with the Duty Occupational Advisor
Employees referred to OH&WBS by their manager must be aware of the referral and of the reasons for the referral – Management Referral (Appendix 2)

The member of staff must sign the Management Referral form to indicate that they have given informed consent to the referral. The management referral form should be sent to OH inbox (mse.occhealth.btuh@nhs.net) in advance of the employee's attendance.

Referring managers must provide full details of their reason for referral and stipulate any specific information that is required. Any background information they have which may aid the OH Physician / Adviser should be provided as this will improve the quality of the outcome report.
Referring managers should state exactly what the problem is or the problem as described by the member of staff.
A current job description should accompany all referrals.

Upon receipt in the Occupational Health department a member of the Occupational Health team will triage all referrals, and it is their decision solely which member of the Occupational Health team sees the employee

Reports from OH&WB to Managers will respond as appropriately as possible to the questions asked whilst maintaining the confidentiality of the staff member. The employee and relevant member of the Employee Relations Team (if requested and appropriate consent given by the eemployee) will receive a copy of any correspondence.

The Occupational Health Adviser / physician reserves the right to withhold letters from employees if they believe that they may cause unnecessary distress; in the event of unstable mental health that the report may cause further deterioration to their mental health and recovery, the manager will be notified of this if appropriate and the individual's GP or treating specialist will be contacted.
The Occupational Health report will include appropriate information to answer the questions asked. It will also address if adjustments are recommended and the duration of those adjustments.

If a referral is required for the employee to see a specialist or to have investigations undertaken within the Trust then a referral via the GP is required as the Occupational Health Department do not have any referring rights
Employees should return to work as soon as the employee is fit to do so.

The duration of rehabilitation; if not to full duties - is at the discretion of the manager and based against the operational need to accommodate the occupational health advice and in compliance with Sickness Absence Trust Management policy.
Medical retirement
A recommendation for retirement can only be made by an appropriately competent person; which will usually be the Occupational Health Physician.
A Management Referral (Appendix 2) must be completed with an indication from management that ill-health retirement to be considered by OH&WBS as part of the assessment
Suspension on medical grounds

The Occupational Health Physician / Occupational Health Adviser may direct suspension of an employee on medical grounds (the grounds for making such a recommendation must be compliant with Trust and employment law). Relevant personnel will be advised of the suspension and the employee will be reviewed by occupation health at an appropriate and pre-agreed interval.
Health surveillance: infection prevention and control of
substances hazardous to health (COSHH)

Legislation requires that people who work with specific substances, or in certain environments, or engage in particular employment, known to be particularly hazardous to health must have tests or examinations as laid down in the regulations applicable to the particular circumstances and as per individual risk assessment for the area. Screening will be offered to these employees on a regular basis, as identified in risk assessment by agreement with the manager.

Food Handlers: all food handlers must be screened prior to commencing employment and following infection prior to return to work. All food handlers must be referred to the department with any skin condition especially on the hands.
Drivers: All driver will be assessed prior to commencing employment using the appropriate DVLA regulations criteria for fitness.

HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C Infected Healthcare Workers: Affected healthcare workers involved in exposure prone procedures (EPP) are assessed and managed according to Department of Health guidance.
Control of infection
All employees should report to OH&WBS as soon as possible any of the following:
Any Needle-stick and Sharps/splash Injuries to assess and monitor the exposure to a potential blood borne virus
Any communicable diseases such as measles and TB
Any infectious diseases that may cause harm to employees or patients that requires a risk assessment, such are varicella or vomiting and diarrhoea whilst at work

The OH&WS will work collaboratively with the Infection Prevention and Control Team IPC and in the event of an outbreak; the service will identify relevant employees, screen and arrange for appropriate treatment to be accessed
Vaccination and immunisation
Immunisation programmes are available to protect employees against infectious diseases such as Tuberculosis, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis A, Chickenpox, Measles, Mumps, Rubella, Pertussis and Influenza.

Please refer to Occupational Health Policies for further information on treatment and management of affected healthcare workers. Policy and Procedure for Occupational Health Management of Tuberculosis and Policy and Procedure for the Management of Needlestick, Sharps and Splash injuries for staff
Exposure prone procedures - EPP

Employees who perform exposure prone procedures in the execution of their duties are required under Department of Health 2007 guidelines to have blood testing for Hepatitis B antibodies and Hepatitis B antigen, Hepatitis C and HIV antibodies. Photo ID will be required by way of a passport, driving license or Trust ID badge.

Any employee member found to be an infectious carrier of a blood borne virus (BBV) will require further testing and may be prohibited from performing exposure prone procedures. Their case will be managed by the Occupational Health Consultant – Refer to Policy for the health clearance and management of health care workers living with bloodborne viruses (Hep B, Hep C and HIV)
Regulatory Bodies have appropriate requirements to fulfil to perform exposure prone procedures which must be complied with.
Needle-stick and sharps injuries

All needle-stick and sharps injuries should be reported to OH&WS during office hours and to A&E outside of office hours as in accordance with the Policy and procedure for the management of needlestick, sharps and splash injuries for staff
Fast-tracking

Fast-tracking access can be applied to both out-patient and hospital admission. GP referrals of Mid and South Essex Hospital NHS Foundation Trust employees will be treated as a priority wherever possible.
All decisions regarding priority for the fast-tracking of staff will be made by consultant staff and such decisions will be ultimately based on clinical priorities.

To take advantage of this scheme the individual must have seen their GP for them to initiate the referral process. Once in the system; OH&WS can expedite the process through liaison with relevant Trust departments. Refer to the Fast Track policy.
Counselling and psychological well-being

The Trust pays for a  hour Employee Assisted Programme (EAP) that offers advice and signposting, plus counselling sessions of up to six sessions if deemed appropriate. The service is available to all MSEFT employees and also extends to family members over the age of
The EAP service can be accessed on assist@c-c-eap.co.uk or 0800 085 1375

An entirely independent confidential counselling service is available to Broomfield MSEFT employees and is site based. With the exception of statistical data, no feedback will be given to the Trust. All Broomfield and Braintree based employees can access up to 6 free sessions. The provision of this confidential service is undertaken by the Trust's Psychological Service who are all qualified counsellors. The counselling service is an organisational member of the British Association for Counselling. Access is via telephone contact on 07795 335048 and leave a message on the answer phone. Every effort will be made to offer an appointment as soon as possible.

Employees also have access to the Essex Partnership University Trust (EPUT) Psychological therapies – HereForYou service that offers both individual support for crisis and counselling needs and team support including reflective sessions, debriefs and team interventions. This service is  hours and can be contacted on hereforyou@nhs.net or by telephone 0344 257
Employees can also refer to ‘Supporting Staff Following Stressful or Traumatic Incidents, Including Complaints and Claims Policy, for further support.
Health and wellbeing
The Occupational Health and Wellbeing service will take an active part in promoting the Health and Wellbeing of the Trust's employees in line with the Employee Health and Wellbeing Strategy.

Collaboration with relevant stakeholders including People and Organisation Development, Employee Relations team in Human Resources, Equality, Diversity and Inclusion team and the Health and Safety team ensures employee health and wellbeing is including in all training, staff development, policies and initiatives that are current and new to the Trust

Promotion of positive health and health education is undertaken at any available opportunity. Health promotion and lifestyle screening will be undertaken in line with any government initiatives i.e. heart disease, obesity, smoking etc. Health education literature is available in the department and a calendar hosts a national and local initiative each month.

The Trust has a Wellbeing Guardian that is a member of the Board who promotes health and wellbeing and seeks assurance to ensure that the Health and Wellbeing Strategy is being implemented across the Trust and includes all employees.
Health promotion
OH&WBS provide health promotion services to all employees and will:
Educate employees regarding Risk Management issues in collaboration with other relevant professionals such as the manual handling team and Display Screen Equipment assessments
Promote general health, to include healthy eating, Flu vaccination and by signposting to various wellbeing agencies
Produce monthly health and wellbeing bulletins with updated resources information
Regularly update the internet and intranets with latest health promotion information
The OH&WBS will co-ordinate the Wellbeing Allies across the Trust who will promote the initiatives.
Communication and implementation

This policy will be disseminated via the corporate communication systems. After approval it will be uploaded onto the intranet to ensure that it is available to all staff and will be new staff will be made aware of this policy at Trust induction.
Training requirements
No specific training requirement for this policy.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the People and Organisational Development Governance group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the relevant staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 1: Pre-placement health questionnaire
Pre-Employment Health Assessment
Welcome to our Trust

We would like to introduce the Occupational Health & Wellbeing Service. The Trust and Occupational Health & Wellbeing service take the health and wellbeing of all staff very seriously. Our role in Occupational Health is both to advise you how to remain well at work; and to advise the Trust about any adaptations that could be made at work to help you do your job.

As part of the COVID-19 Business Continuity Plan we are recruiting certain professionals to assist with the increased demands across the MSE Group. If you currently work in an NHS setting, you will already have had employment health clearance for your role by your existing employer or university. This form allows us to determine whether you require any adjustments to your new COVID-19 role or added health protection.

This health at work questionnaire give us information which helps us to identify any health condition which could pose a risk to you, your colleagues, patients or members of the public or that could affect your ability to undertake the duties of the post you have been offered.

The health information you provide will remain confidential to the Occupational Health & Wellbeing Service. This means that the information you provide in this form will not be disclosed to anyone else without your explicit consent, although some of the information may be used internally as part of routine auditing of the Occupational Health & Wellbeing Service.
What will we do with this form?
If you have provided all the relevant information, we will automatically inform recruitment of the 'clearance' decision.

Section 7 Food Handlers - Only to complete this section
Definition: Where it is used, the term ‘food handler' mainly refers to people who directly touch open food as part of their
work. They can be employed or agency staff.
However, it also includes anyone who may touch food contact surfaces or other surfaces in rooms where open food is
handled. This is because they can also contaminate food by spreading bacteria for example to surfaces that food will
come into contact with, e.g. work tops and food packaging before it is used. They can also contaminate other surfaces
such as door handles which can then contaminate the hands of people who handle food directly for example.
The term can therefore apply to managers, cleaners, maintenance contractors and inspectors for example. It is the effect
of their presence that is important, not the reason for them being there.
Do you expect your job to involve handling food? If Yes please complete the questions in this section If No please go to section 9
